The Ryder Cup is coming

The Ryder Cup is on its way and, as Jake Farrell explains, our sports team will be here to offer their views and opinions throughout the tournament (Thumbnail credit Colin Montgomerie, pictured here at the 2004 Ryder Cup, will hope to captain the European team to success this year. Photo: James Marvin Phelps (mandj98) via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Age of the Idiot

Sean Cole looks into the art of football punditry and lambasts the "generic brand of laddish tedium" currently on our screens (Thumbnail credit James Corden, the host of &quot;an astounding spectacle of guffawing witlessness&quot; during the World Cup is part of a new, and not overly popular, breed of football pundits. Photo: alun.vega via Flickr Creative Commons)

Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

Should we judge the accused as harshly as we are?

Henry Cowen investigates the allegations of spot-fixing within the recent Test match at Lord's and questions whether we are really in a position to judge those accused. (Thumbnail credit Mohammed Amir, here looking disconsolate having been dismissed, faces allegations of spot-fixing. Image: *TreMichLan* via Flickr Creative Commons)

"It was my hometown club growing up" - Luton Chairman Nick Owen on saving his club

Jake Farrell looks back on the 2010 Tour de France. It brought us drama and controversy and, as the weary cyclists rest for another year, Jake reflects on arguably the greatest race in the world. (Thumbnail credit Alberto Contador, seen here celebrating last year's victory, has now three of the last four Tours. Photo: Lynt via Flickr Creative Commons )

Humdrum final round spoils 150th Open Championship

Louis Oosthuizen might have been a worthy champion at St. Andrews last weekend, but a dull final round wasn't what the Open Championship deserved in its 150th year, writes Sam Morgan (Thumbnail credit Louis Oosthuizen holds aloft the famous Claret Jug. Marie Guilpin via Flickr Creative Commons)

Barnett at the double as Derwent eliminate James
